instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00928: What is 820-00928? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA? This is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad. Each CD3215 in the system needs to be functioning in order for any of them to speak to the charger and negotiate receiving 20v from the charger rather than the default 5v that a USB-C charger puts out before communicating with the system. .
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS: What is PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS? PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS is 20v in from the USB-C charger on USB-C powered Macbook Pros..
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v looping one side only
threads.message:
Hello,
I'll give a quick description of the original damage and what I've done till now and then provide some measurements.
I've attached photos with the initial damage and after removing the short on the trackpad connector.

Initially, <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S4_TPAD_FUSE</SIGNAL> was shorted and the short was removed by digging 2 holes in the board.
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> was shorted as well but after injecting current it went away immediately.
I had 5V looping on 2 ports so i reflowed one of the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> (UB400) and now I had 5V stable. I replaced the chip with another one C00 but same 5V stable
I then checked the other 2 ports and they are looping 5V now.
I replaced both <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> (<CHIP>U3100</CHIP> and <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>) on the looping side with no change. So here are the measurements now (After cleaning and drying the board)

Charger Connected to <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.3V Looping
<SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS</SIGNAL> - 5.15V Looping
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> - 3.3V Looping
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL> - 1.8V Looping
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA</SIGNAL> - 1.8V Looping
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> - 1v1 Looping
<SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_4_G3H_SDA</SIGNAL>  - 3.3V Looping
<SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_4_G3H_SCL</SIGNAL> - 3.3v Looping
<SIGNAL>TBA_VDDA</SIGNAL> - 5V Looping
<SIGNAL>USB_XB_CC1</SIGNAL> - 0V
<SIGNAL>USB_XB_CC2</SIGNAL> - 0.98V Looping

Charger Connected to <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.3V Looping
<SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_XA_VBUS</SIGNAL> - 5.15V Looping
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL> - 3.3V Looping
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOD</SIGNAL> - 1.8V Looping
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOA</SIGNAL> - 1.8V Looping
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> - 1v1 Looping
<SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_4_G3H_SDA</SIGNAL>  - 3.3V Looping
<SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_4_G3H_SCL</SIGNAL> - 3.3v Looping
<SIGNAL>TBA_VDDA</SIGNAL> - 5V Looping
<SIGNAL>USB_XA_CC1</SIGNAL> - 0V  
<SIGNAL>USB_XA_CC2</SIGNAL> - 0.98V Looping

Charger Connected to UB400

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_TB_VBUS</SIGNAL> - 5.15V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_TB_LDO</SIGNAL> - 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TB_LDOD</SIGNAL> - 1.8V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TB_LDOA</SIGNAL> - 1.8V
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_TB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> - 1v1
<SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_4_G3H_SDA</SIGNAL>  - 3.1V - 3.3V
<SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_4_G3H_SCL</SIGNAL> - 3.1V - 3.3v
<SIGNAL>TBA_VDDA</SIGNAL> - 5V
<SIGNAL>USB_TB_CC1</SIGNAL> - 0V  
<SIGNAL>USB_TB_CC2</SIGNAL> - 0.98V 

Charger Connected to UB300

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_TA_VBUS</SIGNAL> - 5.15V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO</SIGNAL> - 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TA_LDOD</SIGNAL> - 1.8V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TA_LDOA</SIGNAL> - 1.8V
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_TA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> - 1v1
<SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_4_G3H_SDA</SIGNAL>  - 3.1V - 3.3V
<SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_4_G3H_SCL</SIGNAL> - 3.1V - 3.3v
<SIGNAL>TBA_VDDA</SIGNAL> - 5V
<SIGNAL>USB_TA_CC1</SIGNAL> - 0.98V  
<SIGNAL>USB_TA_CC2</SIGNAL> - 0V

I replaced both <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> and <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> and they are still looping.
Obviously i can't confirm 100% the CD3215C00 I used are good but i don't have any more on hand at the moment to keep on replacing them.
Is that a <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> issue or it can be something else?

Summarised:
2 USB ports are looping at 5V the other 2 have stable 5V. The looping kept even after replacing both of the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>
I have no thermal camera and i can't feel any of the USB controllers to get warm.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v looping one side only
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

The looping ports should be good.
This symptom appears because board try to starts and something else trigger a protection when try to switch to 20V.
You must work on the "fixed" ports, there is a problem...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v looping one side only
threads.message:
Do you mean I have a problem with the 2 that are not looping?
If so, I just replaced both of them with the original <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>'s i had and they are still not looping.

Isn't it when a port is looping it's the issue and when it isn't it's OK?
Also referring to [MEDIA=youtube]vXAK2l1oMZM[/MEDIA]

I also tried to replace the USB rom on both sides and i still have the same results



EDIT:

Taking out <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> makes <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> have stable 5V. Once I replace <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> with another chip both start looping again.
The other 2 ports stay at stable 5V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v looping one side only
threads.message:
Did you take USB ROM from donor board?

How much voltage did you inject on <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>?
Did you find the short, or just noted went away?
If a chip was shorted on <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> and is still on the board, it can have other pins which block some data lines.
It may have power rail internally burnt/open, but can block communication for other chips...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v looping one side only
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 64968, member: 682"]
Did you take USB ROM from donor board?

How much voltage did you inject on <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>?
Did you find the short, or just noted went away?
If a chip was shorted on <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> and is still on the board, it can have other pins which block some data lines.
It may have power rail internally burnt/open, but can block communication for other chips...
[/QUOTE]
I injected under 3V. It went away the moment i injected it and it stopped draining current in split second.
I will replace the SMC and report back as it had originally had a liquid sign on top of it. 

Is there anything else that might cause <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> to be the only <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> causing 5v looping and once removed none of the other controllers loop anymore?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v looping one side only
threads.message:
Diagnosing USB-V areas is not easy job.
And liquid spill is the worst case, as various BGA chips can be affected by (probably) crap accumulated underneath.

Usually, cycling every 5s is sign of board tries to boot on that port.
Some sensor is then triggered and SMC resets the power sequence.

Any reason to quote an entire post visible few centimeters above?
Please, maintain forum aesthetic...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v looping one side only
threads.message:
I am sorry I just clicked reply. No other reason.
I replaced the SMC, exactly the same behavior.

The original liquid damage was affecting only the middle of the logic board, both sides that contain the USB controllers were untouched.
Is it worth stocking another 4x <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>'s and replacing all of them together?
Any guidance on how to proceed to diagnose this is appreciated.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v looping one side only
threads.message:
Liquid on the centre is bad; CPU can be dead now.
At least one USB-C area has been affected too, as you have different USB behaviour left to right.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v looping one side only
threads.message:
Update:

<CHIP>U3200</CHIP> LDO measurements to ground with diode mode compared to the rest

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> = 1647 (the other three measure approx 440)
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA</SIGNAL> = 1385 (the other three measure approx 460)
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL> = 1379 (the other three measure approx 423)
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> = 0L (the other three measure approx 455)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v looping one side only
threads.message:
Looks like <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> is not really soldered on the board.
Reflow it...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v looping one side only
threads.message:
Just a quick update. Turns out i was measuring that specific chip with the probes the other way around It's all good.
I ordered and replaced all 4 <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>'s just to make sure that's not the issue. Still, the same 2 ports are looping

At this point, it's not even about fixing the board. I just want to know what is causing it

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v looping one side only
threads.message:
Do you get now similar readings on all <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips?
You could have a problem witht the ROM chip, or USB 3/Thundernolt controller from that USB-C area.
Maybe bad traces, solders...
